1 – Whether you say ‘Tomato’ or ‘Tomato’, it’s clear that your accent is a defining feature of who you are. Everyone has an accent. Heck, even goats have regional ways of saying ‘bahhhh’. But what’s the science behind language acquisition and does your accent say something about you?

2 – In an American survey, 47% of adults found British accents to be sophisticated whilst 51% thought New York accents were rude. Southern accents were considered nice but possibly uneducated whilst New England accents were considered intelligent. But it turns out that humans have a bias towards others who sound like them or who have the same accent.

3 – Of course, it’s important to distinguish between a native language accent and an additional language accent. English native language accents depend on factors such as geographic location and socio-economic status. For example, a cockney accent of the working-class London is remarkably different than the Queen’s received¹ pronunciation.

4 – However, when it comes to non-native language accents, things are more complicated. If you decided to move to Spain and learn Spanish as an English speaker, you will always speak with an English accent, even if you remain there for decades. After the age of 12, the length of residence has almost no effect on your accent. Studies pinpoint the ideal age as 6 years old with diminishing ability from that point forward.

5 – Interestingly, some stroke patients wake up with an accent completely different to their original voice. This condition is known as the foreign accent syndrome and results from damage to the insular region of the brain, which is responsible for language processing.

6 – One integral aspect of language is the phonemes. Phonemes are the different sound units we use to make up words, some of which are unique to different languages. For example, the phonemes with ‘th’, TH and TH, as in words like ‘the’ and ‘thing’ do not exist in German, making it difficult for German speakers to pronounce these words properly. Conversely, there are many phonemes in other languages that as English speakers, we cannot pronounce or even hear properly.

7 – In a groundbreaking study, 32 American and 32 Japanese 6-month old babies listened to a recording play ‘la la la’ repeatedly. When the recording switched to ‘la la ra’ a toy to the side would light up and play a musical tune. The babies were primed to understand that recognizing the difference between ‘la’ and ‘ra’ led to an audiovisual reward and both the American and Japanese six-month old babies were able to tell the difference and anticipate the toy reward when necessary.

8 – But ‘la’ and ‘ra’ are phonemes that do not exist in the Japanese language. When the study was replicated with 10-12 month old babies, the Japanese babies could not tell the difference between these uniquely English phonemes, showing that a critical period for recognizing phonemes and brain development is at merely 6 months old.

9 – If you try and learn a language, regardless of your age, synaptic connections are made which ultimately create a denser grey matter and stronger white matter networks. In fact, those who grow up in bilingual households are consistently more sensitive to subtle language differences, compared to their monolingual counterparts.

10 – Brain scans have shown that bilingual babies have stronger brain responses in their orbital and prefrontal cortices which are areas linked to focus and problem solving abilities. But have you ever wondered why so many people hate the sound of their own voice? We break down the science and challenge some people to come to terms with their own voice in our new ASAP Thought video. Check it out with the link in the description and subscribe for more weekly science videos.

But please explain why:
1. Even though my dad is from Jamaica, his accent is pretty thin on an everyday basis unless he flips some sort of switch and it becomes extremely thick.

2. About the non-native part: While study Spanish I found myself using the same motions in my mouth when speaking English (my native language). Example: In Spanish we're taught to put our tongues behind our teeth to create a proper "D" sound, and to make our B's sound softer and a little more like V's. The same thing happened once I began studying German. I would find myself often rolling and inhibiting my R's as you would for some German words. It wasn't a conscious thing either, it would just happen when I spoke normally. If this happened to me in a short span of time, I doubt that someone living in a foreign place and speaking their native language wouldn't adopt some form of "accent".
I could be wrong, but I find it interesting.

I profoundly disagree with the stance on the invariability of accents in the context of foreign language learning once you have passed a certain age. Indeed, there is some consensus in the field of linguistics which deals with language acquisition to assume that it will be more challenging for older learners of, say, English to move their accents towards a more native-like pronunciation in the target language. However, having been a language learner for several decades myself, I can by no means subscribe to the idea that your accent will more easily fossilize if you start learning a foreign language at a later point in your life. In my opinion, there are a whole variety of different factors which contribute to the success rate of your acquisition process, including a general aptitude for learning languages (which has a lot to do with how well you can perceive the different sounds of the target language and then imitate them), your personal involvement with the language, i.e. how much time you dedicate to your learning process (the more intensely you immerse yourself in the language, the greater the output will be), as well as an intrinsic motivation to fully commit to the endeavour. Just to reiterate: I am not suggesting that the results of linguistic research should be disavowed or considered to be invalid, it couldn't be farther from it. Yet, I would like to encourage people not to be blinded by something which, in my book anyway, is nothing more than a common myth that can easily be debunked. I am in the process of learning Italian as a third foreign language, and I am unwilling to buy my way into believing that I cannot master a language because some linguists carried out research on it which made them claim that I can't do it because I have reached a certain age. Individuals have different strengths and weaknesses, and if you're really a talented linguists, I don't think there's anything that should stop you from disproving such a general statement. If you've really got your heart set on it, you can and will succeed.

Whether you say ‘Tomato’ or ‘Tomato’, it’s clear that your accent is a defining feature of who you are. Everyone has an accent. Heck, even goats have regional ways of saying ‘bahhhh’. But what’s the science behind language acquisition and does your accent say something about you?

2 – In an American survey, 47% of adults found British accents to be sophisticated whilst 51% thought New York accents were rude. Southern accents were considered nice but possibly uneducated whilst New England accents were considered intelligent. But it turns out that humans have a bias towards others who sound like them or who have the same accent.

3 – Of course, it’s important to distinguish between a native language accent and an additional language accent. English native language accents depend on factors such as geographic location and socio-economic status. For example, a cockney accent of the working-class London is remarkably different than the Queen’s received¹pronunciation.

4 – However, when it comes to non-native language accents, things are more complicated. If you decided to move to Spain and learn Spanish as an English speaker, you will always speak with an English accent, even if you remain there for decades. After the age of 12, the length of residence has almost no effect on your accent. Studies pinpoint the ideal age as 6 years old with diminishing ability from that point forward.

5 – Interestingly, some stroke patients wake up with an accent completely different to their original voice. This condition is known as the foreign accent syndrome and results from damage to the insular region of the brain, which is responsible for language processing.

6 – One integral aspect of language is the phonemes. Phonemes are the different sound units we use to make up words, some of which are unique to different languages. For example, the phonemes with ‘th’, TH and TH, as in words like ‘the’ and ‘thing’ do not exist in German, making it difficult for German speakers to pronounce these words properly. Conversely, there are many phonemes in other languages that as English speakers, we cannot pronounce or even hear properly.

7 – In a groundbreaking study, 32 American and 32 Japanese 6-month old babies listened to a recording play ‘la la la’ repeatedly. When the recording switched to ‘la la ra’ a toy to the side would light up and play a musical tune. The babies were primed to understand that recognizing the difference between ‘la’ and ‘ra’ led to an audiovisual reward and both the American and Japanese six-month old babies were able to tell the difference and anticipate the toy reward when necessary.

8 – But ‘la’ and ‘ra’ are phonemes that do not exist in the Japanese language. When the study was replicated with 10-12 month old babies, the Japanese babies could not tell the difference between these uniquely English phonemes, showing that a critical period for recognizing phonemes and brain development is at merely 6 months old.

9 – If you try and learn a language, regardless of your age, synaptic connections are made which ultimately create a denser grey matter and stronger white matter networks. In fact, those who grow up in bilingual households are consistently more sensitive to subtle language differences, compared to their monolingual counterparts.

10 – Brain scans have shown that bilingual babies have stronger brain responses in their orbital and prefrontal cortices which are areas linked to focus and problem solving abilities. But have you ever wondered why so many people hate the sound of their own voice? We break down the science and challenge some people to come to terms with their own voice in our new ASAP Thought video. Check it out with the link in the description and subscribe for more weekly science videos.

My whole family sounds off for our area. Most of us sound close, but not quite. My dad and I almost sound normal, but my grandpa and brother are really off. Keep in mind that everyone except my dad has lived in our state all our lives. My brother used to have a very distinct British accent. He ancidently convinced a former girlfriend that he was a foreign exchange student. He eventually learned to manually change his voice' s accent, but he has never mastered our specific area accent. My grandpa on the other hand, nobody has any idea what he sounds like. He has a very strong accent that nobody can quite seem to place. We are not entirely sure why he sounds different. We believe that my bother and Grandpa might sound like that because of various health conditions they were born with, but no one is quite sure. The rest of us (besides dad who spent the first 2 years of his life in a different state) likely just sound odd from being influenced by their accents growing up.

Personally, I'm close enough that people rarely ever mention anything, but sometimes they do. Once I went to a camp, and a girl from a state over was there too. Apparently they decided to analyze random accents over the camp. On the last day, they came up to me and asked where I was from because they couldn't recognise the accent. When I said I came from the same general area as most of the others, they were really surprised. I asked them to list some examples of how I was different, and they listed some subtle pronunciation differences I never noticed before. I was never told I sounded slightly different before, so this situation was a bit of an eye opener for me.

Queens, Brooklyn and central Long Island accents are distinctively different from each other and are equally distinctive from Buffalo, Syracuse, or the Finger Lakes or the Adirondack regions. Even speech patterns are different (do you stand on line or in line, or drink soda or pop?) There is also a distinctive tempo difference between New York accents (and the rest of the country for that matter.) Hollywood portrays the South as backward so, people who get their education from TV or movies don't know better. It's funny I'm nowhere near fluent in French, but whenever I say a French name or say something in what little French I know, I don't have an English accent.

Because my dad's first language is French, in fact he only became decently fluent in English a few years before I was born. Plus his side of the family? Only about half of them are bilingual. So I was exposed to a lot of French growing up, and even when hearing English as a baby, a good chunk had a Montreal accent.

My friend who didn't have any French exposure outside of school lessons, yet took courses outside of school to become fluent, is always so annoyed that she has such a strong accent when she speaks French while I don't have an accent at all. A small correction, if I may: 
  
 Japanese does not not have a 'ra' and a 'la' phoneme, it's just that they're the same. ら in hiragana(or ラ in katakana) are called the 'ra' kana, but actually you'll hear a lot of Japanese people say these as 'la' just as often. An example of this would be the word レモン, which is written and therefore also said as 'remon'. But, since r is the same as l, this can just as well be pronounced as 'lemon'.  
  
TL;DR: Japanese does have ra and la phonemes, they just happen to be the same.

you can most definitely adopt a native accent when you are immersed (ie move) in a different setting for an extended period of time. Example I know someone from Spain and she has lived here for her entire life, and she has a perfect Spanish accent (as a native) + a very pleasant flat American accent; you would never know she even spoke Spanish, let alone completely fluent Spanish. I guess the key is immersion and dedication. Personally everyone here who is a native English speaker (like myself) should consider themselves super lucky, English is weird as hell and our vowel sounds are more like diphthongs whereas in other languages they're clear-cut. Knowing how to speak English + write it is something that few non-native people ever figure out. Other languages are not too bad, especially the Romance languages. bilingualism is a blessing :-)

Your claim about accents is general and not entirely true. It's very rare that anyone will wholly retain their accent if they live somewhere else. They usually pick up small features which make them distinguishable from both their naive accent and where they've moved. Just simply talking to someone with a different accent can lead to this kind of accommodation very quickly. While a person may never gain a full accent, it's certainly not impossible or unheard of for people to entirely change their accent depending on where they're living, especially if they spend a lot of time moving between a few select places.
This video was painful. <th> is not a phoneme. /θ/ and /ð/ are phonemes associated with the orthographic <th>.
Depending on where you go, Japanese does include /l/ as a phoneme, but it will be retracted. Alternatively, others will use the flap /ɾ/ (For note, most research papers I see suggest that [ɾ] is the phoneme, but the IPA database suggests [l]). However, [l] and [ɹ] are most definitely allophones in Japanese. Additionally, just because it's a phoneme doesn't mean Japanese doesn't contain or use the other sounds that were offered. Suggesting that phonemes are all a language uses is silly. British English has, Standardly, 4 or 5 different variations of /k/. Some accents will replace [k] with [x], yet [x] is not a phoneme of English.

Additionally, you didn't actually answer your title. You gave us some facts, but didn't really tell us what our accent tells us. Which, generally, isn't much. Accent alone often reflects very little apart from the area you live. But language taken as a whole can reflect much more.

I grew up in central Indiana in a region that linguists categorize as the "Hoosier Nexus" which essentially is a accent neutral region of pronunciation squeezed between other more distinct accents. It is the least colorful accent region with maybe 1 or possibly 2 phenom distinctions out of dozens, however it means that speakers from this small area speak a sort of basic English. Two benefits that come from this is that how I speak is essentially how most newscasters train to speak and what you will hear as the average in the media. The second is that speech recognition programs understand my commands more often that other people. My wife from Illinois still confuses Cortana and Siri, my father-in-law originally from South Dakota is even worse. Also, I am very good at noticing subtle differences in how others speak and have been able to differentiate between someone from Columbus OH and Cincinnati OH.

I live in Java island, Indonesia,. East Java, Central Java, and Special Region of Yogyakarta has the same language, which is Javanese, but heck, we have different accents, western part of Central Java has 'ngapak Javanese accent' while Yogyakarta and Eastern part of Central Java, East Java have 'medok Javanese accent'
I live in western part of Central Java, and had ngapak accent, but then my brother went to college in Yogyakarta, and he kinda mocked me for being ngapak because it sounded funny, so I changed my accent to medok accent, I don't think I had trouble during the transition. So I used medok accent even though I live in ngapak accent society.
Then I got into college, I go to college in West Java, here the society uses Sundanese language. Majority of the students here from Jakarta which uses Betawi and Gaul accent and from Bandung which uses Sundanese accent. And tadaa I changed my accent again so that I can fit in in campus life. [note: I changed my accent to Gaul accent when talking to Jakarta-Bandung students, because people from West Java and Jakarta usually look down at Javanese accents as low-class accent. Gaul itself means cool, as in 'cool kids' 'cool hat bro'] This things happen to most Javanese people who go to West Java or Jakarta to work/study because we, Javanese people, look up, at gaul accent, as high-class accent. You can easily find Javanese who fit in so well in gaul accent society, but when he or she gather around with javanese people, he/she can speak fluently in her/his original javanese accent.

I myself am trilingual..........I speak Chavacano, which is a Spanish-based creole in the Philippines as my native or mother-tongue language, then I learned Filipino, our national language and is the standard form of Tagalog, which is another Philippine native language while I am also learning English (which is really American English) where we also developed our own Philippine English dialect with our own Philippine English slang words and vocabularies just like how American, British, and Australian English are similar but still different.
So when growing up, I also get so sensitive with sound, with having an ear defect since I was 7....I also loved and appreciated other languages' sounds, phonemes, and accents making me trying to learn how to pronounce foreign sounds even foreign accents by mimicking sounds like those hard sounds in Arabic, tones in Thai, and distinguishing similar sounding vowels of other languages, aspirated consonants versus non-aspirated, etc.

In the Philippines, it's a bit hard to be born here with three languages (Native Mother Tongue Language, Filipino, and English) plus learning other regional native languages for advantage in communication. Other Filipinos are even multilingual or even polyglots in learning various Philippine regional languages and other foreign international languages.
I myself, learned easily how to switch pronunciations of sounds per language I am using, also shifting from one grammar and sentence construction to another, learning wide vocabulary, and trying to change accents as much as I could.

I learned different "r" sounds....the not much rolled and tapping "r" of English...and the semi-rolled "r" of Filipino........ and the rolled "r" sound of Spanish language being my native language is a Spanish creole with the "r" (ere) and the "rr" (erre or doble ere) which are different sounds for us here. :D

I think that the intonation also counts, as well as the pronunciation itself. The British "upper class" accent sound extremely sophisticated to me, not because I view those people as sophisticated, but because the way they speak is subtle, they speak softly, slowly, they don't use as many shortened words, and they don't change their pitch or volume while speaking. A slow and precise articulation sounds more sophisticated to everyone's ears than an accent that is fast and fluctuating. Let' me just write it down and every single person reading this comment will immediately have an opinion on which is more sophisticated:

"How's dem hot dawgs mayne?"

"Excuse me, but will the hot dogs be ready soon?"

Even people who don't understand a word of english think that some accents are more sophisticated than others.

I pick up the accent of the person with whom I'm speaking, particularly in English. My own "natural state" of English is a sort of posh-London accent, whenever I'm in London people hardly even believe I'm not English. But I consider myself having grown up sort of, semi-bilingual; as soon as I knew how to read my parents would never let me see movies with voice-over to Swedish, I'd "have" to watch it in English with subtitles. So being a massive Harry Potter fan growing up, I seem to have picked up on the generic accents from there. We also started having formal English lessons at the age of 7, but previous to that I could already say "Pass the milk, please" and count to ten.
But this ordeal with picking up accents also goes for when I speak Dutch and French, I sound very different speaking to my Wallonian friend and my teacher from Lyon.
I didn't learn French until I was 16, and I didn't learn Dutch until I was 20, so that's a thing...

I think it's clear that people have a bias towards people who sound like them. A close family member of mine used to work for a large British holiday company whose name started with a 'T'. There was a customer satisfaction thing a number of years ago amongst hotels they set holidaymakers to in Greece: the greatest problem aside from hoteliers not speaking good English? Television news. 'But why', thought head office, 'was this particularly high in certain hotels- even those with international channels?'
Long story short, they didn't like CNN, Bloomberg or France 24, and not because of the content- they wanted BBC World News because they 'didn't trust' how the Americans or nondescript Europeans sounded. I don't think this is xenophobic reaction specific to Brits- we all feel a bias towards our own voices.

As a Phonetics and Phonology student, although I loved the video, I have to point out that three of the graphemes (the symbol that goes between slanted bars or lines) used do not correspond to the phonemes they were supposed to be representing, and actually don't really exist in the IPA chart of English phonemes. The sound |ch| is represented by /tʃ/ (t-esh ligature), |sh| by /ʃ/ (esh), and the phoneme |th| corresponds to: /Θ/ (theta) in the case of "thing", and /ð/ (voiced dental fricative or Eth) in the case of the word "the". But again, I loved this video, amazing!

An EFL teacher here. There is one piece of information not correct in your video. At 1:08 you said that "After the length of 12, the length of stay has no effect on your accent." This is completely false. Changing your accent depends on three factors: motivation, need, and how auditory you are. Auditory people, like me, can pick up and imitate people's accents after listening to them for a few minutes. Auditory people are also able to hear very subtle notes in music and can notice change very quickly. Motivation and need are two other factors that can influence your accent. I personally have no interest in French so even if I live them for 100 years, I will still have an American accent but I love Spanish so if I live in Spain for even a year, I will start to sound like Spaniards. The information you presented is not scientifically accurate. But thanks for the video

Instead of two different types of accents it is much easier to refer to it like this. Variations within the same language are dialects. Variations in a languages when coming from another language is an accent. A native English speaker using French will have an English or American accent but a native English speaker in London has a different dialect than a native English speaker in Texas.

From my own personal experience, the statement about people being unable to pick up a non-native language accent is rather ignorant and dismisses a lot of what happens when people do speak non-native languages/ accents. A good friend of mine had a strong aussie accent when I met him (he's Chinese), which has since ebbed away, another one had lived in England and would speak with a bit of an accent. For me, after living in Brazil for a year.(and I was able to learn different phonemes) I came back with a strong Brazilian accent when I spoke in English- my native language. Also I noticed I've changed my accent subconsciously after being around other English speakers in different regions- after returning home from university I realized I had adopted a more neutral accent while living in the city. To say that native speakers hold onto their accents no matter what they speak is false. Accents are more fluid than that, and there should be more studies about that.

1:08 "After the age of 12, the length of residence has almost no effect on your accent."
VS.
2:52 "..., those who have grown up in bilingual households are consistently more sensitive to subtle language differences..."

the effect of length of residence can only be measured, in this case, statistically. therefore, this is an average: some people outside the critical period do make gains—sometimes very large ones—that do correlate roughly with length of stay.

some other people fail completely to learn a language at all, even when living in the country for decades.

while I think we can say that the critical period is probably a real thing, TIME is the wrong factor to correlate to, especially when talking about language learning outside the critical period.

language is probably the single most poorly taught subject in the world. some places may teach it really well, but I doubt that very much. in Japanese schools, for example, where every student studies English for all of high school and junior high school, at the very least, and a large proportion of students study English outside of school as well — many even starting from age 4 — almost no one can speak English well at all.

basically, this is because the main portion—the bit in school—is all taught to achieve test results (critical for college entrance) and even now all but forces students to learn English using Japanese. this bypasses our brain's natural ability to learn languages, and forces students to think about English in the least useful way that's possible.

but even with all that, some people learn to speak English really well. the point is that it's not so much how long (although length is obviously a factor) or even how it's taught (although the right teaching method makes a massive difference), it finally comes down to precisely HOW each student uses their own brain. the very few students who happen to think about it in the right way, and get the right few nudges along the way come out the other end speaking well.

"those who have grown up in bilingual households" already know what it's like to use two different languages and shift between them, so they're more likely to approach it in the right way—and quickly see the complete uselessness of exercises like, "put these words into the accusative case."

so, just because you're an adult, doesn't mean your accent will always be bad any more than it means you won't be able to learn the language at all. it depends on how you use your brain.

I don't fully agree with the whole "you can't lose the accent thing". As a general rule it is true; the older we get the more we lose the ability to effortlessly mimick sounds and soundpatterns. So from a certain age up you do not "just pick it up" anymore. - But you can still put in the effort to study the phonetics of a certain accent and learn how to pronounce it. That is how actors learn accents. Of course it is always a conscious process and you have to put effort in it for a long time and you may slip up and fall back into your "natural accent" as soon as you encounter a soundpattern you have not yet learned.
Technically, if you learned the whole phonetic alphabet and how to form each sound correctly, you could read/speak any language without an accent.

That aside: I am interested how coming generations are influenced: because of the internet and especially youtube and the likes young children are exposed to a range of languages and their phonetic oddities. I wonder if that has any effect on accents / language learning in general.

K & c --> kh (خ) usually
Q --> qaaf
h --> h with a dot underneath (ح)
r --> rolled
s --> s (never z)
Occasionally insert ع in beginning of words that start with vowels
i --> ē
short e, ā --> IPA [e(:)]
short oo --> IPA [u(:)]
ah, aw, short o --> British aw
long o --> IPA [o]
short u, short a --> IPA [a(:)] (similar to short a)

About phonemes: The h in Mohammad isn't an English h; it's ح in Arabic and ח in Hebrew. The q's in AL-QUAEDA and Qur'an are uvular, and there's an `ayn (ع, Hebrew ע) between the a and e in AL-QUAEDA. Gaza has a gheyn (غ), not a g. Hanukkah, Hasidic, humus, and tehinah have neither h sounds nor kh sounds; they have ח (Arabic ح) sounds. It's not heth or kheth; it's h(with a dot underneath)eth.
